text: No matter what challenges we face this year, Montanans will prevail. Our spirit and sense of community will carry us through. Happy #406Day to all Montanans. https://t.co/M0SSpfD3oy

As we continue to do everything possible to protect Montanans from the spread of this virus, making sure children and families in our state don’t go hungry is a crucial priority. https://t.co/DGNkk7c3CG
We stay at home to slow the spread and save lives, and to protect frontline health care workers in both urban and rural communities.

Today we solemnly learned of another death in Montana from COVID-19. My heart goes out to the loved ones of this fellow Montanan. Each loss of life impacts another community and another family – and indeed, all of us through our shared bond as Montanans.
Thank you, Montanans, for everything you're doing to play your part in slowing the spread of this virus. https://t.co/sg9nGBqhoU

I'm calling for an extension to the Census deadline to accommodate COVID-19 health and safety measures. In Montana, we must ensure that everyone is counted. Our schools, hospitals, highways, communities and families depend on it. https://t.co/rSfj8DyvrE

Today is #CensusDay2020 and @LtGovMikeCooney and I are asking all Montanans to fill our their 2020 Census form. In fact, you can do so while staying at home to slow the spread of COVID-19. https://t.co/NbaVan4Ate
Our rural and urban hospitals serve on the frontlines of this crisis and they need our support to continue providing lifesaving care across the state. https://t.co/Sj93Fe859b

So long as this virus forces Montanans to stay home to save lives, Montanans need a home to stay in. This order ensures that a loss of income won’t lead to Montanans losing their homes or having their heat turned off. https://t.co/01cFqa74u1
Read the full directive here: https://t.co/QevwDv46QA

While we love our visitors, we would ask that you not come visit while Montanans are watching out for one another by staying at home. Today I directed that travelers arriving from another state or country to Montana for non-work-related purposes undergo a 14-day self-quarantine. https://t.co/DkOf0HzLow

Whether they work in a three bed rural clinic or our largest healthcare system, Montana’s doctors are against a lot these days. And they have risen to every challenge. Join me in thanking Montana’s doctors on this #NationalDoctors Day.

We lost two more Montanans, a total of four, to COVID-19. This is a blow to our statewide community and a heartbreaking reminder to us all that we must continue to do everything we can to slow the spread of this disease.

I’m saddened that a 2nd Montanan has died from COVID-19. No matter in which community we live, the impact of each loss of life has a ripple effect throughout the state and serves as a reminder of how serious this disease is. Our hearts go out to the loved ones of this Montanan.

Thank you to:
The grocery store employees who work tirelessly 
The truck drivers who keep shelves stocked 
The emergency responders on duty
The teachers who are providing high quality education in creative ways

We’re cheering for all those on the frontlines of COVID-19. https://t.co/xAk4BcIKeT

During the Stay at Home order, Montanans are still able and encouraged to responsibly enjoy our public lands. Follow social distancing requirements, avoid crowded trailheads, and recreate near the communities you live. It’s up to all of us to slow the spread of COVID-19. https://t.co/Kt9sJbq5oQ

Thank you to Montana’s health workers – doctors, nurses, CNAs, pharmacists and pharmacy techs, custodians, receptionists, and more – who fight COVID-19, while ensuring Montanans can access other essential medical care to stay healthy. Your work is the backbone of this battle.

I’m heartbroken to learn of Montana’s first death due to COVID-19. Montana truly is one big small town – this news hits us hard, but we’re in this together. My family and I send our love and support to the family, friends, and community of our fellow Montanan.
We are all in this together. We can get out in front of this together. And when the time comes again, we will rebuild a stronger community.
In order to have a healthy economy we need a healthy population. We cannot rebuild our economic strength without doing everything we can now to flatten the curve and slow the spread of this virus.
I am taking these measures today because we need to stay in front of this pandemic and slow the growth of infections.

There’s no doubt that COVID-19 is causing a lot of hardship for Montana families. It’s also causing incredible hardships for our front line doctors, nurses and other hospital staff across the country.
Businesses and operations can find out if they are deemed essential in the directive at this link: https://t.co/THMrG3XMhO

In consultation with public health and emergency management experts, I have determined that to protect public health and human safety, it is essential, to the maximum extent possible, individuals stay at home or at their place of residence.

Locally elected officials best understand the voting needs of their communities. We can protect both the public’s health at a time we face unprecedented challenges with COVID-19 and the right to vote with this direction. https://t.co/fshAphPiJ6

These hardworking ER doctors are right – time is a valuable resource to fight COVID-19. Staying home slows the spread of this virus and buys us time. Thank you to all the Montanans doing their part. https://t.co/Yy6jr05y5K
RT @jtkemper: Here are the 2020 @BengalsHigh Basketball Seniors! Enjoy! @Hayden24Ferg @logan32291235 Ayden Fasbender @c_g_bullock @emilyfel…
We must take COVID-19 seriously, and we must prepare for the curve to go up. But with a continued focus on working together as Montanans, our state can get out in front of this.

At the same time we are extending closures, we are also preparing for a potential increase of patients at our hospitals. We are doing everything we can as a state to prepare to take care of critically ill patients and ensure there is hospital space and supplies to respond.
Stay at home, if you can. Don’t hang out in big groups. Stay six feet part from others, when you can. Don’t go to the grocery store every single day, plan ahead to limit your contact with others.

Montanans have an obligation to slow the spread of this virus. Our fellow Montanans can all continue to set a good example for each other in adhering to social distancing directives – and know that it will save lives.
It is the actions we are taking today – and actions businesses, individuals and each of us take today and in the immediate future that will lessen the spread in Montana.

I am prohibiting non-essential social and recreational gatherings of individuals outside of a home or place of residence of greater than ten people, if a distance of at least six feet between individuals cannot be maintained.

Today I announced the extension of closures of public schools and dine-in food service, alcoholic beverage businesses and other entities through April 10 and mandated social distancing measures to slow the spread of COVID-19 in Montana. https://t.co/P90qL9d7Ff
Don’t forget to look for the peace and goodness in every day https://t.co/7pw1Uajm5d

Social distancing is paramount to slowing the spread of COVID-19, but we also must prepare for a potential surge in critically ill patients. Today’s actions ensure we can focus on providing urgently needed quality care without delay.  https://t.co/FQ7gUaEq9u

On the 10th anniversary of the Affordable Care Act, I’m reminded of how far we’ve come to expand coverage through Medicaid expansion and to those with preexisting conditions. Now is the time to do more to improve access and affordability to care, not strip it away.
Access to health care is more important than ever as we face the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our hospitals and front line providers cannot be forgotten. They need the resources and support to do their incredibly difficult jobs, among mounting challenges.

The package should also include an increase in SNAP benefits for families struggling to keep food on their tables during these unprecedented times, as well as protections for workers who are facing tough challenges such as unemployment and evictions.
Increasing the Federal Medical Assistance Percentage to 6% is not enough. It must be increased to 12% so that states can continue to rapidly respond to the impacts on our healthcare system.

We - Democrat and Republican Governors - have asked for at least $150 billion in direct aid to states, giving governors the flexibility to direct this money to where we need it most in our communities during this time.
Governors are on the front lines of the fight against COVID-19. The Senate must give us the resources we need to help our states.
Montanans have always rallied together in times of crisis. It’s time that we do so again. https://t.co/eD0s7GdIor
Montanans across the state have been impacted by COVID-19 and extending the deadline gives taxpayers breathing room without having to worry about interest or penalties. https://t.co/i9Du7WK0Bk

As the Senate deliberates an economic stimulus package, governors are pushing for the inclusion of unrestricted fiscal support. States are on the forefront of this fight - we must be able to address the economic needs of our citizens during this crisis. https://t.co/cbflrOa1y4
@mikedennison I remember seeing your son at the national bee, Mike!

We face further extraordinary health, economic, and social risks if we do not act now. I do not take this decision lightly and it was done so in consultation with public health professionals. Montanans, too, need to take this seriously. It’s up to all of us to stop the spread.

Montanans young and old, in urban and rural communities, have tested positive for coronavirus. This virus impacts us all, and these actions are imperative to protecting our friends and neighbors. https://t.co/j16GGVl9Ez

Today I issued a travel advisory recommending all Montanans who return from international travel to self-quarantine for 14 days. By staying home after traveling, Montanans can play a key role in preventing COVID-19 spread in their community. https://t.co/U4eDqnUmP7
Help them help you — stay home to  flatten the curve so our healthcare facilities aren’t overwhelmed and our health workers minimize their exposure to COVID-19. https://t.co/EKCBDwpyT1

I’d like to thank providers across the state who are on the front lines, balancing routine care with the new volume created by COVID-19. We truly couldn’t do this without you, and I admire your fearless dedication to Montanans.

Expanding telemedicine will provide the physical, mental, and substance use care Montanans need without overwhelming health care facilities responding to COVID-19 or risking unnecessary exposure. https://t.co/cDjohNPitW

This is a significant step in containing the spread of coronavirus. We know that the lack of health insurance often results in the delay of seeing a doctor or being turned away, which could further fuel this pandemic and put other Montanans at risk. https://t.co/lTOTopfzW3

These rules will ensure that workers impacted by COVID-19, whether it’s because they’ve been laid off, are quarantined, or need to take care of a family member, can do so without worrying about how they will make ends meet during these difficult times. https://t.co/EeTJJCUxOW

I praise the leadership of local communities for enacting social distancing orders. The ability to slow new infections is in our hands and our friends and neighbors are counting on us to do the right thing. https://t.co/p0zEHzwGZk

Yesterday I announced several measures to slow the spread of COVID-19 in Montana, including closing public K-12 schools and recommending limiting all gatherings. It’s going to take all of us working together to overcome these challenging and dynamic times. https://t.co/D3sGAEzgD3
My top priority is protecting the health and safety of Montanans, particularly our most vulnerable, at a time when we face the potential for extraordinary health risks from coronavirus in our state.
Social distancing is a primary protective measure to flatten the curve of this virus. I cannot underscore the seriousness of following these measures to help our neighbors, friends, and families.
I encourage businesses to do everything they can to support Montana families as well.

I recognize that our schools often serve as a lifeline for families and that this decision is going to have disruption on Montanans over the coming weeks. I’m committed to working with schools, communities and public health to minimize the impact.

Today I announced measures to slow the spread of COVID-19 and protect vulnerable Montanans, including closing public K-12 schools for two weeks, strongly recommending social distancing measures, and limiting visitation at nursing home facilities. https://t.co/9VnUKCzOZt

As Montanans, I trust we will do everything we can to help our fellow citizens. We have been planning and preparing for these days to come to Montana. In the coming days and weeks, we will continue to make decisions in the best interest of the public’s health.

The small sacrifices we make now – missing out on a cancelled event, avoiding crowds and enjoying time with small groups of healthy family and friends, and staying home if you feel sick – means keeping more folks healthy in the long run.

I can’t stress enough the importance of the role of the public in helping us mitigate the impact of this virus. The person ahead of you in line at the grocery store could be among those most at risk of falling ill to the virus.

I amended Montana's state of emergency to align the effective timeframe with the federal state of emergency announced by the President. This means that our state’s emergency response will be in effect as long as necessary to allow us to continue to mobilize state resources.
The state lab is performing testing and disclosing results today and will be performing testing 7 days a week starting Monday.

Today I hosted a call with Montana press to provide an update on Montana's four positive COVID-19 cases and share additional response efforts. I’m pleased to report that all four patients are at home and recovering.
As our public health officials work relentlessly to prevent further spread, I urge all Montanans to continue efforts to plan and follow public health recommendations to take the proper precautions.

Four people in Montana have tested positive for COVID-19. We've been monitoring this rapidly evolving situation and vigorously preparing for this virus to reach Montana, making today's news unsurprising. https://t.co/uW8wE1R46X
Our state is preparing for coronavirus to come to Montana and we will be prepared to respond all along the way.

Declaring a state of emergency means I can mobilize all available state resources to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 on Montanans. That's why I'm doing so now, before we have a confirmed case in our state. https://t.co/2XEUCKM6kJ

I agree with this approach that takes the necessary precautions to keep students safe and healthy. I have no doubt the Montana University System will continue to provide a quality education to students during this time, while prioritizing the public’s health. https://t.co/rfVVGkpCvd
We will continue to monitor the patient in Maryland and remain committed to preparing for coronavirus to reach Montana.

Earlier today it was announced a Montanan visiting Maryland tested presumptive positive for COVID-19. We can now confirm the patient did not have coronavirus while she was in Montana and has not been in the state since November of last year.
Lisa and I are sending all our good thoughts and love to the patient.

Public health officials are working closely with Maryland to confirm case details on when this individual was last in Montana. We are committed to providing Montanans with accurate, transparent information and are working to ensure details will be provided as soon as possible. https://t.co/hyPT881jp9
Every student deserves an equal shot at an education. Dual enrollment helps to make that possible, while saving families money on tuition costs. https://t.co/cHUysdGzIT

The Montana Boy Scouts presented me with their annual Eagle Scout report today. The journey Eagle Scouts take represent one of the core values we share as Montanans: commitment to service. 

I have no doubt their great work will benefit this state for generations to come. https://t.co/9nubvRlrfy

Today is about recognizing the women trailblazers who came before and the many still to come as we fight to ensure equal rights. On #InternationalWomensDay , I'm grateful to all of you and to the most important women in my life. https://t.co/f3yozsfadY

Since 2014, Lisa and I have partnered with @nokidhungry to increase access to school breakfast, ensuring that 61% (up from 46%) of Montana’s food insecure students have what they need to learn. As #NSBW2020 draws to a close, I’d like to thank the folks who work to make that 100%. https://t.co/QHByj0vmts

Our firefighters put their long-term health on the line each day in service to Montanans. I stopped by @Local521 this week to discuss the presumptive illness protections we passed last session and see how firefighters are taking extra steps to stay safe and healthy. @mtproff https://t.co/Zd2bHAwTE0

Each year, we participate in the Doorsteps to Kid Packs food drive in Helena. You can help by placing kid-friendly food items on your doorstep today, to be collected by @AmeriCorps members. Thanks for your commitment to ending childhood hunger!
- The Bullock Family https://t.co/FHIhxku5rG

Above all, use the same public health prevention measures that are used to prevent influenza. Wash your hands, avoid touching your eyes/nose/mouth, stay home if you are sick, cover your cough/sneeze, and clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.
I urge Montanans to listen to their local public health officials and use reputable sources for information, such as the state's health department website: https://t.co/6JWxBlT99i

This is the public health event that Montana practices for. We’ve conducted similar responses in the past. Looking out for our family, friends and neighbors is what we do. We've been preparing and will continue to address this evolving situation.

While there are no current diagnosed cases of coronavirus in Montana, we’re taking steps to prepare and respond in the event the outbreak reaches our state. Today, I announced the activation of the Governor’s Coronavirus Task Force. https://t.co/QiF18ZxcQd

It's National School Breakfast Week! Students who eat school breakfast have increased attentiveness, improved behavior, and higher attendance. It was great to kick off the week helping students in Billings start their day off right. https://t.co/DVmBTKZkH8

Law enforcement is often the first on the scene when responding to a patient in cardiac arrest. We are grateful to the Helmsley Charitable Trust for investing in Montana to help save lives. https://t.co/AQdkhLFrPP

Over a century ago Theodore Roosevelt gave us "the great central task of leaving this land an even better land." In this age of political polarization, our return to shared values and our work to conserve public lands is what we need to chart that path. https://t.co/mNMz522Hf7

I joined Little Shell Tribe leaders today to discuss the Census. After becoming federally recognized, the Tribe is eligible to be accurately counted for the first time ever and have access to federal dollars for education, health care, and community planning. https://t.co/ygJ5w45v1a

Montana is making progress, thanks to the tireless dedication of professionals and communities, and every life saved makes a difference. We cannot stop until even more lives are saved and until we ensure every Montanan has the support they need. https://t.co/xOYLAXb8Wr

Thanks to the folks @RockiesProject and @WstrnPriorities for being part of the force to protect our public lands, one of America’s greatest ideas and greatest treasures (and for inviting me to Colorado to brag about Montana) https://t.co/s87zviAuhL

We announced the continuation of the One-Two-Free initiative which allows high school students to complete college courses tuition-free & get a jumpstart on their college education. Free dual enrollment courses have already saved families more than $24 million in tuition. https://t.co/8ixVvGcJti
@MegSimps @EWodin You never worked her that hard back in the day!

It couldn't be clearer that the President is choosing to fund his border wall over keeping our citizen soldiers and Airmen safe. I won't stand idly by until Montana's National Guard members are given what they are owed.

As Commander in Chief of the Montana National Guard, the decision to send our Soldiers and Airmen anywhere is one of the most difficult decisions I make. It's unacceptable to me that we are doing so with outdated aircraft.

Montana Air National Guard members are currently operating a fleet from 1974, using technology no longer used by airlines. In order to pay for the border wall, the President has announced he is shifting funds that will further delay the modernization of this C-130 aircraft.
Books or movies? Yes. https://t.co/QmSBSyGj2X

We can also agree that our public lands are under attack by Washington D.C. - facing some of the greatest threats I have seen in my lifetime. We must recommit ourselves to doing everything we can to protect, preserve, and promote our national treasures.
While we come from all walks of life, we can agree on one thing: America's greatest idea is indeed worth protecting.
Folks out West have a special appreciation for our public lands, and we know our public lands are our heritage, our birthright, and our great equalizer. https://t.co/mc1dnFG0Y6

Strong government-to-government relationships benefit Indian Country and all of Montana. Thanks to Little Shell Tribe Chairman Gerald Gray and National Congress of American Indians @PresFawnSharp for joining us for the Tribal Relations Training. https://t.co/yeVcX5MvXU

Kalispell’s remarkable RoboScouts are headed to Houston in April to compete in @firstlegoleague. I was so impressed with their skills, and I can’t wait to see what they do this year and in twenty years. https://t.co/Qi3Hlz5UNB
@AliVelshi @JoyAnnReid Congratulations on the new show!
Grateful for my Valentine, today and each and every day. https://t.co/V8OHDUXejj

I enjoyed a visit to Flathead Valley Community College to chat with students at their Brewing Academy. Montana is a leader in the industry and the college is responding to growing demands to find workers with the right skills. I even got to sample the hazy IPA - I was impressed! https://t.co/zQGOIMiPH4

This tax credit will benefit nearly 75,000 working Montanans and help them provide basics for their families such as groceries and gas, while also investing dollars in our communities to support local economies.  https://t.co/Onrnet9L4X

We are excited to share the early recommendations of my Montana Climate Solutions Council and encourage the engagement of all Montanans. Our state's efforts to craft home grown solutions will be critical to addressing climate change.  https://t.co/AQ5x38QaNO

These Girl Scouts sure know how to drive a hard bargain. They each had a solid pitch, which means I’m going home with way too many boxes of Thin Mints and Tagalongs. https://t.co/TnsgmQkBKS

I don’t want my three kids or yours to be saddled with this Administration’s mistakes. Billionaires don’t need a tax break, especially when it’s bankrolled by the hardworking people of our state and country.

Cutting farm assistance programs, obliterating health coverage, robbing elderly and disabled Americans of crucial services, sidelining rural America, and slashing the Land and Water Conservation Fund is the opposite of what the President calls “A Budget for America’s Future.”

Every budget – from the statehouse to the White House – ought to be a reflection of our values. The President is showing he doesn’t share Montana’s values by proposing to cut the services that build up our economy and make our state great – all to give his pals a tax break.

Sarah Rhoads, head of Amazon Air, former fighter pilot and Butte, Montana native, participated in @GovLarryHogan’s panel on modernizing America’s infrastructure during @NatlGovsAssoc Winter Meeting. Another example of an incredible Montanan making a profound difference. https://t.co/ctHBsHftja

It’s always an honor to join other governors in making sure military leaders in Washington give support to citizen soldiers. As the longest serving member on the Council of Governors, I always insist on decisions in the best interest of National Guard members and their families. https://t.co/htsxB3zcrh

Where I come from, 18 holes is not the same as sleeping under the stars. With Trump's latest attack on our national monuments, he ought to reconsider leaving the comforts of his golf courses to come out west. https://t.co/v9nhGHEHuz

Welcome back @Astro_Christina and congratulations on your record setting flight. Your contributions will support the U.S. in future expeditions and will inspire our future leaders, especially young girls, for generations to come. Way to make Montana proud. https://t.co/tG5rOnR8Hf

I had the honor of swearing in @AmeriCorps members who will serve with Montana Conservation Corps and work to protect our outdoor spaces. Thank you for your spirit and for choosing to serve the Big Sky State. https://t.co/fDoKfWaDko

No matter which side you’re on - or whether you’re just watching for the snacks and commercials - we can all agree that the strength and determination of Montana’s Mike Person is something to cheer on and be proud of today.

I am thankful Montana’s farmers will be able to access the critical resources they need following a difficult harvest season. https://t.co/bmrMWO95CA

Democrats should not be connecting the ability to be heard to money. Period.     

DNC did that in setting debate requirements & in removing them. You link money & politics, process gets corrupted. Dems should be rejecting money’s influence, not letting it guide our primary.

Make no mistake, this is just another effort by the Trump administration to gut coverage, drive up costs, and discriminate against patients with costly medical conditions. In Montana, we will keep working to enhance health care, not strip it away. https://t.co/d1qep8gLzC

The story told of this historic day to the generations that follow us will also be one of tirelessness, of determination, and of a long overdue correction of history.
There’s no better way to start off 2020 than celebrating the victorious end of a 157-year long fight as the Little Shell Tribe finally received federal recognition. https://t.co/M06NQFpjQA

Service members and their families already sacrifice so much and Lt. Col. Ian McBeth took his call of duty even further. Lisa and I send our condolences to the family and we will always be grateful for Ian’s service to our state, our nation and the world. https://t.co/adi6H3crAR

The U.S Supreme Court just finished hearing arguments in a case that attacks Montana’s constitution. Our state was there today to defend public education and the First Amendment - and we will always be there to stand up against attempts to undermine our values as Montanans.

Less well known about the court’s reasoning justifying new corporate spending: It would be accompanied by a vigorous system of campaign finance disclosure. 

America’s experience since Citizens United has been the opposite. https://t.co/v3dEpsYtcA

Iowans and the nation are better off for his decades of meaningful work in ensuring a vibrant democracy, bridging divides in communities, and standing up for rural America. Thank you, Tom.

Tom has been a hero of mine since I was in my 30's. As I was first shaping my path in public service as an assistant attorney general for the state of Montana, his efforts fighting for consumer protections for the people of Iowa inspired me.
Today my longtime friend and mentor @AGIowa Tom Miller becomes the longest serving attorney general in the history of the country.
